summary: The World Peace Council (WPC) is an organization that appears in several documents. One document mentions a disruption at a WPC meeting caused by a Chinese delegate who denounced President Kennedy after expressions of sorrow for his death. Other documents detail U.S. participants at a WPC meeting in Budapest in 1971, including speeches on the Vietnam War, a posthumous award to Martin Luther King Jr., and the re-election of Herbert Aptheker and Carlton Goodlett to the Presidential Board. The documents also list American participants at the conference.
significance: The World Peace Council is mentioned in the context of the JFK assassination due to a Chinese delegate disrupting a meeting by denouncing President Kennedy after his death. The other documents do not directly relate to the JFK assassination, but provide context about the WPC's activities and participants during the 1970s.
